messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Ilja Preuss [mailto:preuss@...]
>
> To me, the second piece of code explicitely communicates that I want to
> assert the code in the block to throw an exception, whereas the first
> doesn't. It also seems to much better align with the other Junit assert
> idioms.

The more I look at it, the more I agree with you Ilja.

1: You know an exception was called, but you don't know which one, unless
you cascade catches like this:

} catch (MyException ex) {
} catch (Exception ex) {
fail("MyException not thrown");
}

This may not be important to you, but I can imagine several cases where you
would want to know if it threw a specific Exception.

> > >>public void testForException() {
> > >> try {
> > >> doSomethingThatShouldThrowMyException();
> > >> fail("MyException not thrown");
> > >> } catch (MyException ex) {
> > >> }
> > >>}
> > > We are currently trying something along the lines of
> > >
> > > public void testForException() {
> > > assertThrows(MyException.class, new Block() {
> > > public void execute() throws Exception {
> > > doSomethingThatShouldThrowMyException();
> > > }
> > > });
> > > }
